alerts.headline: Flood Watch issued June 12 at 2:27PM CDT until June 12 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
alerts.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be
possible.

* WHERE...Portions of Arkansas, including the following counties,
Columbia, Hempstead, Howard, Lafayette, Little River, Miller,
Nevada, Sevier and Union, northwest Louisiana, including the
following parishes, Bienville, Bossier, Caddo, Claiborne, De Soto,
Natchitoches, Red River, Sabine and Webster, southeast Oklahoma,
including the following county, McCurtain, and Texas, including
the following counties, Angelina, Bowie, Camp, Cass, Cherokee,
Franklin, Gregg, Harrison, Marion, Morris, Nacogdoches, Panola,
Red River, Rusk, Sabine, San Augustine, Shelby, Smith, Titus,
Upshur and Wood.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM CDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur
in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be
flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Scattered showers and thunderstorms will continue to develop
through early this evening. These storms may result in
excessive rainfall and an additional 1 to 2 inches of
rainfall.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

alerts.headline: Flood Warning issued June 12 at 5:09PM CDT until June 12 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
alerts.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.

* WHERE...Portions of south central and southeast Texas, including
the following counties, in south central Texas, Jackson. In
southeast Texas, Brazoria, Matagorda and Wharton.

* WHEN...Until 900 PM CDT.

* IMPACTS...Flooding of roads, rivers, creeks, streams, and other
low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Expect many
areas of standing water. It will take several hours for all the
water from earlier storms to work through local drainage systems
and recede.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 504 PM CDT, Between 6 and 14 inches of rain have fallen
earlier today. No more  significant rain is anticipated going
into the overnight hours, but standing water will remain slow
to recede.
- Flooding impacts will continue, but no additional rainfall is
expected.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Matagorda, Lake Jackson, Angleton, Bay City, Freeport, Clute,
Edna, Palacios, West Columbia, Sweeny, Surfside Beach, South
Texas Nuclear Plant, Richwood, Brazoria, Jones Creek, Ganado,
Oyster Creek, Bailey's Prairie, La Ward and Markham.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

alerts.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 12 at 5:51PM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
alerts.description:
At 551 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong
thunderstorms along a line extending from 7 miles northeast of La
Reforma to near La Joya City Hall. Movement was northeast at 15 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Palmview, Penitas, Sullivan City, La Joya, Palmhurst, Encino,
Garciasville, Linn, Los Ebanos, and Rachal.

This includes the following highways...
US Highway 83 between mile markers 828 and 850.
US Highway 77 between mile markers 738 and 744.
US Highway 281 between mile markers 716 and 764.

alerts.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 12 at 10:04AM MDT until June 17 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
alerts.description:
* WHAT...For Friday, temperatures around 105. For Saturday through
Monday, temperatures as high as 109.

* WHERE...Eastern/Central El Paso County, Rio Grande Valley of
Eastern El Paso/Western Hudspeth Counties, and Rio Grande Valley
of Eastern Hudspeth County.

* WHEN...From noon Friday to midnight MDT Monday Night.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures may cause heat illnesses.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The hottest days will be Sunday and Monday
with a low risk for highs at or above 110. The heat advisory will
almost certainly need an areal expansion by Saturday or Sunday,
and there is a low to moderate risk the heat advisory will need to
continue for Tuesday.

thunderstorms along a line extending from 7 miles northeast of La

possible.

US Highway 77 between mile markers 738 and 744.
US Highway 281 between mile markers 716 and 764.

alerts.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 12 at 5:51PM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
alerts.description:
At 551 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong
thunderstorms along a line extending from 7 miles northeast of La
Reforma to near La Joya City Hall. Movement was northeast at 15 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Palmview, Penitas, Sullivan City, La Joya, Palmhurst, Encino,
Garciasville, Linn, Los Ebanos, and Rachal.

This includes the following highways...
US Highway 83 between mile markers 828 and 850.
US Highway 77 between mile markers 738 and 744.
US Highway 281 between mile markers 716 and 764.

alerts.headline: Flood Warning issued June 12 at 5:09PM CDT until June 12 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
alerts.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.

* WHERE...Portions of south central and southeast Texas, including
the following counties, in south central Texas, Jackson. In
southeast Texas, Brazoria, Matagorda and Wharton.

* WHEN...Until 900 PM CDT.

* IMPACTS...Flooding of roads, rivers, creeks, streams, and other
low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Expect many
areas of standing water. It will take several hours for all the
water from earlier storms to work through local drainage systems
and recede.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 504 PM CDT, Between 6 and 14 inches of rain have fallen
earlier today. No more  significant rain is anticipated going
into the overnight hours, but standing water will remain slow
to recede.
- Flooding impacts will continue, but no additional rainfall is
expected.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Matagorda, Lake Jackson, Angleton, Bay City, Freeport, Clute,
Edna, Palacios, West Columbia, Sweeny, Surfside Beach, South
Texas Nuclear Plant, Richwood, Brazoria, Jones Creek, Ganado,
Oyster Creek, Bailey's Prairie, La Ward and Markham.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

alerts.headline: Flood Watch issued June 12 at 3:50PM CDT until June 13 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
alerts.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be
possible.

* WHERE...Portions of south central and southeast Texas, including
the following areas, in south central Texas, Coastal Jackson and
Inland Jackson. In southeast Texas, Brazoria Islands, Coastal
Brazoria, Coastal Matagorda, Inland Brazoria, Inland Matagorda and
Matagorda Islands.

* WHEN...Through Friday evening.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.

in poor drainage and urban areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- Rainfall flooding is not anticipated overnight. However,
scattered showers and thunderstorms are expected to develop
early Friday. Areas that received heavy rainfall today may be
more prone to additional flood impacts if heavy rainfall
moves over these areas again.
